questions.question: A database structure that improves the speed of data retrieval operations.
questions.explanation: An index creates a data structure that allows faster access to rows in a table.

questions.question: SQL command to create an index on a table.
questions.explanation: CREATE INDEX is used to build an index on one or more columns of a table.

questions.question: An index that does not allow duplicate values.
questions.explanation: A unique index enforces that all values in the indexed column must be distinct.

questions.question: An index that determines the physical order of data in a table.
questions.explanation: A clustered index sorts and stores the data rows in the table based on the index key.

questions.question: An index stored separately from the data with pointers to data rows.
questions.explanation: A non-clustered index has a structure separate from data rows and contains pointers.

questions.question: The most common data structure used for database indexes.
questions.explanation: B-trees provide balanced access times and are widely used for database indexing.

questions.question: An index on two or more columns.
questions.explanation: A composite index includes multiple columns to optimize queries using those columns together.

questions.question: SQL command to remove an index from a table.
questions.explanation: DROP INDEX deletes an existing index from the database.

questions.question: An index designed for efficient text searching.
questions.explanation: Full-text indexes enable fast searching of text content within large text fields.

questions.question: The column or columns on which an index is created.
questions.explanation: The index key is the column or set of columns that the index is built on.
